Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned something about how we analyze text with computers.
Learned a lot about linguistics and the intersection of linguistics and computer science.
I learned a wide variety of techniques for NLP.
Learn computational approaches to understanding human language. First half of the class is based on more traditional language models, second half is mostly machine learning.
Intro to NLP techniques, language modelling etc.
Learned machine learning basics, information theory, statistics and probability, quite a lot now that I think about it. I was told going into it that it would be a survey course and this was correct.
This was my first machine learning class, so it was cool to learn about neural networks.
I learned about interesting questions in linguistics. Unfortunately, I did not learn any skills that could be used to solve these problems.

Learnt about a range of topics related to NLP, such as POS tagging, sentiment analysis, Machine translation, Dimensionality reduction, similarity metrics, Parsing algorithms (like CKY, and probabilistic CKY), neural networks among other topics. Also learnt about coding in tensorflow and pytorch, which are very useful tools. Also learnt a lot about linguistics, which is something I have never learnt about before.
You will get a broad understanding of the various NLP tasks/techniques
Great introducion to nlp. Different kinds of grammars, intro to machine translation, parsing...
Solid overview of many subjects related to natural language processing with the healthy smattering of linguistics.

In this course, I learned several softwares related to NLP, but all without a lot of depth. This course was absolutely a survey course, but for this reason I learned very little about any specific NLP topic and would have trouble replicating some of the problem sets we did in this class on my own.
We got a great overview of the various tasks and methods involved in natural language processing
I learned a little bit about many, many issues that we face in Natural Language Processing.
They asked this question on the Exam, I answered it there.
The course helped familiarize me with Python, and I learned a lot about linguistics and NLP algorithms.

The class was a great survey of the field of natural language processing. I learned various algorithms, such as Viterbi and CKY, to complete different NLP tasks such as part-of-speech tagging and parsing a sentence. I also learned how to build a recursive and reccurent neural network in TensorFlow and PyTorch. The class also focused quite a bit on the linguistics behind the natural language phenomena.
You learn about many NLP topics (it is a survey class)

I learned a bunch of different topics and methods in Natural Language Processing. Specifically POS tagging, syntax parsing, sentence similarity methods, machine translation methods including the noisy channel model and neural network autoencoders, sentiment analysis using recursive neural networks.
If you want to learn some about machine learning it is a good start.
Introduction to the field of NLP and basic applications of NLP.
I learned about dynamic programing, neural networks, and statistical parsing. More importantly, I learned about the engineering approach used to implement natural language systems.

Much better appreciation of how broad the field is and the state of the art in different areas. Understanding of the mathematical models and techniques that underlie NLP. Some experience using libraries for NLP and AI. The meaning of syzygy.

Knowledge: NLP concepts such as part of speech tagging (hidden markov models, bigrams, trigrams); syntax and parsing (CFG, CCG, feature-based grammars and unification, dependency parses and graph-based MST techniques); semantics (vector based techniques, taxonomies like wordnet); translation (IBM models, expectation maximization, RNNs); sentiment analysis (recursive NNs and compositional semantics); dialogue (recursive structure theory); dimensionality reduction (SVD). Analyzing the quality of such methods.
Skills: implementation of algorithms for many of the above, specifically HMMs, CCG, Recursive NNs, and RNNs.
Insights: difficulty of NLP tasks; various types of ambiguities; organizing training data. Various simiplified models of the mind's use of language.
An overview of the field of Natural language processing and methods in deep learning.
Viterbi, CKY, HMMs, deep learning, neural nets (cool stuff that enables natural language processing in different ways)
I learned the basics of a lot of Natural Language Processing techniques.

weaknesses: your grade in this class depends heavily on the midterm and final, despite the fact that given the hands-on style of machine learning, much more learning is done through the psets in the first place. Unfortunately, a bunch of material on psets is available online, and sometimes they're ripped straight from the tutorial. Overall, I'm pretty disappointed in the quality of this course.
Drago is only ok at lecturing. He writes slides and just reads them. There is a lot of material.

The material is interesting, however it is taught poorly. Drago moves through the slides very quickly and by the end of every class I would feel like I had a lot of information thrown at me without any clear structure. 

Drago would focus more on linguistics in lecture rather than the computational tasks needed for the psets. Pset 4 in particular was very difficult: we were asked to use Tensorflow and train a neural network without any real direction. 

My other complaint was with the overall disorganization in the class. We would randomly move between lecture slides out of order. Piazza was a mess of questions and notes. And TAs would randomly cancel or reschedule office hours. The class could have really benefited from a Google Calendar and a simple, clear reading-list.
The class was very fast paced and I wish we spent a little more time on certain topics.

This course covered a wide variety of material, broadening students' knowledge. No topics were covered in depth. The slides were the longest that I have seen in any Yale course.

However, the instructor took an encyclopedic approach to NLP, going so far as to give the slides numerical titles that impeded understanding. This approach made it more difficult to understand the connections between the lectures. This encyclopedic approach also led the instructor to fairly equally weight the different parts of his encyclopedia. The result was that too much time was spent on simpler topics such as Bayes theorem and not enough time was spent on the more complex parts of the course.
Class was pretty good. Some of the lectures did jump around a bit and there was sometimes a disconnect between when we did stuff in lecture and when it was on the problem sets.

Good coverage of material.

Very broad and a bit of disconnect between a lot of the lecture and assignments. Needs original assignments
TF and ULA team did a great job with piazza responses etc.
The class definitely favors students with a strong background in linguistics. More information on what to study for exams would be helpful.

There could be better information on what will be covered for the test. I found it difficult to know what exactly to study. Also a strong background in linguistics would be helpful, but I did not know this. Tests focused more on linguistics than NLP code.
Lectures were a bit all over the place.
The lectures are interesting. The textbook is horrible. The homework assignments barely teach you anything.
for a survey course, exam questions could be pretty specific

This class was great in the first half; we learned about part of speech tagging in a hands on way. The lectures had a lot of key words that sound pretty similar, and its never really clear what is testable material, so the midterm was rough, but everyone in the class is in the same boat.
The second half of the courses problem sets were just lazy. It was a fill-in-the-blank coding problem, so you never really knew the full scope of the algorithm, and also one of the problem sets was literally a pytorch tutorial. These problem sets would have been much better if they had expanded on or changed that tutorial.
Overall, the course is really ambitious in its scope and you come away from it knowing, at least, what is possible and what resources you should seek out. I dont know if you actually learn any tangible skills, which is disappointing given that we actually did have coding problem sets.

The course was very well structured into different sections, and covered a range of material, so had a very large width of material. Went deeper into specific topics in homeworks. Material was very well presented by Professor Drago.
It is a survey course, so do not expect that you will end the semester *truly* knowing how NLP works. You do cover a lot of fascinating stuff though.
Very interesting lectures, cool psets, the tas are also extremely helpful
The lectures were a lot and we went over many topics very quickly. It was hard to follow and absorb all the content in the way that it was taught.
Solid overview of many topics.

I thought this course would have benefitted from much more specific information related to what topics were/were not important to focus on. I also would have appreciated problem sets that were not pulled directly from the internet.
The PowerPoints, while thorough, were not particularly engaging and often did not fully explain the complex topics and equations. The organization of the course was great though.

The strength of this course is that Professor Drago is very knowledgeable about his field.

The weakness of the course is that in the latter half of the course, you hardly learn anything from the problem sets because a lot of the functions you use are imported. I had little idea about what exactly was going on in my code. The latter half of assignments were as if I was filling in the blanks of staff-created code.

Strengths: interesting subject material, Drago puts together a good syllabus
Weaknesses: Lectures aren't always the most engaging, some problem sets were pretty random and were hard but not in a way that I learned much

Both this and AI should be changed pretty significantly, I think. It's a frustrating mix of highly theoretical lectures with 5 topics we never touch on a problem set for every one that we do. The problem with this is that the lectures are taught so quickly with no opportunity to check understanding.
I know it's a survey course, that doesn't mean you should sprint through material. Choose a few simple versions of things and teach the algorithm, give us problems or written problem sets to check understanding, and then give us the technical problem set where we do some code relating to either that algorithm or a more complicated version of the same idea. As is, stuff like the EM algorithm just wizzes past, with the lecture outlining the algorithm and then absolutely no attempt made (not even on either exam) to give anyone an oppotunity to play with it enough to understand it.

The problem sets are also exceptionally lazy. I should not be able to accidently find the code to complete an assaignment by googling pytorch tutorials. Pacman in AI was a great example of using other peoples code well, and Othello was about equally good. Basically all the NLP problem sets were immensley frustrating until I accidently found the place it was taken from, after which they were dissappointing. 
It should not be a TA's responsibility to write something as complicated as these problem sets tend to be. Some time should be invested as these courses are improved and developed into writing some specific manageable problems sets for these classes. This will seem more feasible if we give up always doing some incredible cutting edge version of a technique, and instead focus on an example that is simple enough that 90% of the code does not need to be written for us to be able to do it.
The material was very interesting, although sometimes lecture felt a bit too fast paced.

The strengths of this course include that it is quite resourceful. All the lecture slides are online and the TAs are pretty helpful for the homework assignments. On the other hand, I felt like the lecture glossed over some complex topics and I felt like I had to learn them independently. It would have been great if we spent more time on certain topics instead of focusing on covering as many topics as possible.

The class covered many interesting topics and I got exposure to topics I did not know about previously. However, the class also covered TOO many topics, so I feel like I did not have a solid grip on any one topic.

Strength: covered a lot of aspects of NLP
Weakness: knowledge is highly scattered and poorly organized

I think the strengths were the topics covered, which were interesting, and the homeworks, especially the first 3. However I think the lectures were a weak point, where the organization was confusing and too many topics were attempted to be covered.
I wish that the slides were more thorough. Also, the problem sets were not original which was a little frustrating.

Strengths: as promised, it provides a survey of topics in the field of NLP
Weaknesses: lacks depth and rigor; it's not as good as its equivalents at Stanford and Berkeley

Great course, super interesting topics that are presented in a way that make them sufficiently challenging to be interesting but also accessible. I'd say the weaknesses could come from the expanse of topics, that at some point I got a little lost because we did a 100 things. That may just be inherent in a survey course though. One improvement for me would be the exams, because I felt the midterm wasn't a great measure of my knowledge in the class.

Strengths: Challenging course material. Drago is very skilled at NLP and gave great insights to the field.

Weaknesses: Psets were much harder than the content covered in class. Spending more time to discuss coding implementation in class would have helped.

I liked the speed at which material was covered. This was an overview course, and I believe that I did get a decent overview of the field. However, the homework assignment varied wildly in quality. At times they were really interesting, but some of them taught almost nothing and required endless debugging more than anything else.

Strengths:
Lots of pretty interesting material. Psets were very cool and satisfying. Teaching staff was very responsive and on top of things. Material was well organized. Drago is very nice and enthusiastic!

Weaknesses:
--Structure / use of lecture time could have been better. It often seemed like we spent a long time just going over vocabulary or repeating very simple concepts, then there would be only 1 slide on some really complicated but very important idea. As a result, I didn't feel like I learned very much from the lecture: much of the time I was bored and easily distracted, then when some genuinely new / challenging material come up, we didn't give it nearly enough attention so I failed to learn it at all. Parts of the class seemed less like a class teaching you NLP, and more like an advertisement for a class teaching you NLP. That is to say, it sometimes felt like we were getting a "crash course" for a whole semester. Maybe that just means there was too much material to cover it all in depth-- I'm not sure.
--For the love of God, put titles in filenames of the slideshows.
--This will sound like a joke but it is not. Please believe me: the lighting in that room is corrosive to focus. I was falling asleep even on 9 hours of sleep, EVEN during the final when I really needed to pay attention. Something about that place just saps your energy completely.

Strengths: Excellent job touching in some detail on all major topics, and drawing connections between. Good balance of theory and application (generally more application). Problem sets cool and appropriately difficult.
Improvements: the sentiment analysis pset involved recursive neural nets, which were really hard, but awesome once you got it. More help on this pset. The final pset was a little cookie-cutter of PyTorch machine translation. Professor could take more questions in class.

Strengths: PSETs were interesting but really relied on specific applications.
Weaknesses: PSETs relied too much on specific lines of code, lectures did not really have to do with PSETs.

psets leave you out to dry. You better be ready for some serious confusion. I liked the fact that it was a survey course -- you get to learn a bunch of stuff about the subject. You can specialize later!
The strengths are the organized way in which content is presented. The weeknesses are the lecture slides are not always super detailed and it can be hard to follow along with the pace of the class.
Only if you want a vocabulary of topics to discover on your own in the field of machine learning and natural language processing.
NLP goes from literally learning what a noun is to implementing state of the art neural networks. Be prepared to do a lot of learning towards the end of the semester. Cool class though.
I learned a lot of linguistics and using computer science to approach linguistics.

I would not recommend this course to another student unless they are very interested in learning a little bit about a wide variety of topics. Instead, a student should take a linguistics course to learn about the theoretical aspects of natural language and a machine learning course to learn the statistical aspects.
Sure. I wouldn't say its a must-take class, but its a good introduction to a topic that is increasingly important.
Yes. a pretty reasonable work load, useful and broadly applicable topics

NLP is a lot more statistics/data science based than I thought it was before taking the course, so understand that while the material you are working with is human language, most of the day-to-day work is highly quantitative. That said, there is plenty of neat linguistics information to be learned through the year. 

Also, this course is a SURVEY, so there will be lots of breadth over many NLP topics but very little depth in any of them, which is exactly what Drago tells you at the beginning of the term. I think he is doing an advanced topics in NLP course now, too, so maybe take this one and if you like one part of it especially then focus on that in the advanced topics course.
Yes, although know that it is a survey course.
yes

As youve probably heard, this course is a bit of a mess. Dragos slide decks are unintuitively organized, theres a lot of trivia to know, and lecture is not super engaging. However, Drago as a person to talk to about research is great, and NLP is a fascinating subject. This may not be the best way to present it, so if youre not already interested in the subject dont take it. However, if you are interested and you put in enough time, this class is great.
Yes. The material was very interesting and useful, and Professor Drago is a great professor. Enjoyed the homeworks and lectures.
Yes absolutely, great cs elective.
No I would not. I feel that I did not learn a lot throughout the course of the semester and it was more memorizing than really understanding core natural language processing concepts.
If youre interested in AI and ML stuff then this is a good bet!

Yes, because I think the material is important to learn. But if you are not really interested in NLP, you should not take this course. It is not taught well and is too broad, so unless you are willing to learn the specifics on your own you will not learn very much in this class. However, the problem sets are very fun and engaging.
NLP is an interesting part of computer science. This is the kind of class that kind of sucks during, but youll come out okay and be glad you took it.

If you want a general idea of what problems we face in Natural Language Processing and where to find the resources to attack those issues, then take this course! I would say about half of the course was not fulfilling because the concepts we learned were very abstract and never really implemented.

If you're at all interested in NLP you should take it. I definitely learned a lot about NLP and it wasn't a particularly high workload course. That said, sometimes I felt that we went back and forth between different topics and it was hard to get a complete picture. I thought the later 2 psets were badly constructed in a way that I didn't learn much.

I mean, no, but just because it's so often frustrating. I come to this class already knowing most of the things (from other math, statistics, and machine learning courses) that it intends to teach, and I'm still constantly struggling to guess what the correct line or two of missing code is in a problem set. I can only imagine how frustrating it would be for someone who is actually trying to learn this.
I would recommend this course. The Psets are well structured, and Drago knows a lot about NLP!
Absolutely! It's a great introduction to a variety of topics in natural language processing. The assignments are quite hefty sometimes but overall very enjoyable.
I would recommend the class as long as you understand it is a survey course. Also, maybe wait a year or two for the class to get more organized.

This course covers some very interesting topics in a rather poor manner. The first half of the course is pretty solid, the homeworks interesting, relevant, and appropriately challenging. However, the neural network portion of the class was poorly taught and the homeworks for that section did not help me learn. Overall, the professor attempted to teach too many things, which made studying for exams hard. That said, Natural Language Processing is a great way to learn about some broadly useful topics in computer science. Unfortunately you won't learn them very well because there are too many of them.

The material is really interesting, but the course has some issues. The problem sets are mostly taken from other places. Lectures can be pretty interesting, but also hard to follow at times. I would suggest starting by going online and just reading about machine learning and reading the text that accompanies this course.
I would recommend the course, but you need to moderate your expectations. If you're looking for a rigorous and intellectually challenging course, I would recommend something else instead.
Yes, definitely. Very interesting and Drago is one of the best professors I've had here.
Yes. NLP is a growing field and worth exploring.
Yeah I think it's a cool elective. You gain familiarity with something that will definitely be useful going forward, and it isn't too much of a time suck.
Excellent overview of NLP, including foundational theory and modern techniques. Advanced NLP to come. Do come to class, and stay up to speed by doing examples from class.
Would recommend if you're interested in NLP.
Yeah, it's a hella important field. You'll feel more comfortable with some important concepts after taking this course.
Yes! I think it gave me a strong foundation in the material.
